fast3d.math

Class Vector3d

  • java.lang.Object
    • fast3d.math.Vector3d

  • public class Vector3d
extends java.lang.Object
    a vector3d is a set of 3 double-coordinates, named x, y and z
    the vectors dimension determines it's count of coordinates
    a vector can be interpreted as a location or direction in it's 3d universe
    Author:
    Tim Trense

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      Vector2d shaded
      to shade a vertex means to calculate its position on a viewers camera-screen
      to not calculate that multiple times for one image, the shaded position can be buffered here
      byte shadedFrameID
      if multiple images are calculated with changes in the scenery or camera movement in between it is necessary to know whether the shaded-field-value is valid or was from previous calculations
      double x
      the coordinate x of the vector
      first dimensions coordinate
      double y
      the coordinate y of the vector
      second dimensions coordinate
      double z
      the coordinate z of the vector
      third dimensions coordinate

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Vector3d(double x, double y, double z)
      constructs a new vector based on the given coordinates

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Vector3d add(Vector3d t)
      adds the coordinates of the parameter to the coordinates of this
      does not change the parameter
      double angleTo(Vector3d v)
      calculates the angle between this and the parameter-vector in radiant
      both vectors are direction-vectors and for that calculation interpreted as arrows laying on the 3d-space-origin
      does not change the parameter
      static Vector3d calculateAverage(Vector3d... vecs)
      the average vector is:
      does not change the parameter
      the center position (if the given vectors were interpreted as positions) the middle-direction (if the given vectors were interpreted as directions)
      Vector2d clipTo2dXY()
      just cut off the z-coordinate
      Vector2d clipTo2dXZ()
      just cut off the y-coordinate
      Vector2d clipTo2dYZ()
      just cut off the x-coordinate
      Vector3d clone() 
      Vector3d constrain(double min, double max)
      constrains the coordinates to the given range
      if a coordinate is lower than min, it will be set to min
      if a coordinate is higher than max, it will be set to max
      after this method call all coordinates will be within the interval [min,max], including the limits
      Vector3d constrainLength(double min, double max)
      constrains the length to the given range
      if this length is lower than min, it will be scaled to min
      if this length is higher than max, it will be scaled to max
      Vector3d crossP(Vector3d b)
      the cross-product of two vectors is a vector that is orthogonal to the parameters
      it does matter in which order the parameters are given.
      static Vector3d crossP(Vector3d a, Vector3d b)
      the cross-product of two vectors is a vector that is orthogonal to the parameters
      it does matter in which order the parameters are given.
      double distanceTo(Vector3d target)
      calculates the length of the difference vector given by to(target)
      does not change the parameter
      double distanceToSquared(Vector3d target)
      calculates the square of the length of the difference vector given by to(target)
      does not change the parameter
      double dotP(Vector3d v)
      calculates the dot-product of this and the parameter
      does not change both the parameter or this
      static double dotP(Vector3d a, Vector3d b)
      the dot product of two vectors is an double that can represent part of the angle between the parameters
      the dotP is positive if the angle between the vectors is pointed, a negative value otherwise
      if the parameter-vectors are orthogonal, the result will be 0
      it does not matter in which order the parameters are given
      boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
      compares this with the parameter and returns false if the parameter is not of the same type
      does not change the parameter
      static Vector3d forward() 
      double getCoordinate(int dimensionIndex) 
      double[] getCoordinates() 
      int getDimension()
      will always return 3
      returns the length of the array given by getCoordinates();
      static double getRatio(Vector3d a, Vector3d b)
      returns the ratio between the two given parallel vectors or Double.NaN if they are not parallel
      if given vectors a and b the ratio is defined as:
      a = ratio * b so that ratio = a / b;
      int getX()
      casts the x value to int
      int getY()
      casts the y value to int
      int getZ()
      casts the z value to int
      void invalidateShaded()
      indicate that a prior shade in the same frame is now invalid, due to changes of the coordinate
      Vector3d invert()
      inverts this vector
      this will point in the opposite direction, but with the same length
      static boolean isFinite(Vector3d v)
      checks whether the given vector is not null and all it's coordinates are finite
      boolean isNormalized() 
      boolean isOrthogonal(Vector3d v)
      checks, whether the parameter-vector is orthogonal
      it may have another length
      boolean isParallel(Vector3d v)
      checks, whether the parameter-vector has the same direction
      it may have another length
      does not change the parameter
      boolean isSameOrientated(Vector3d v)
      checks, whether the parameter-vector has the same direction and orientation
      it may have another length
      does not change the parameter
      boolean isZero()
      checks all coordinates to be 0d
      double length()
      calculates the length of the vector as a n-dimensional arrow
      double lengthSquared()
      calculates the squared length of the vector as a n-dimensional arrow
      faster than length()
      Vector3d multiply(Vector3d t)
      multiplies the coordinates of the parameter to the coordinates of this
      does not change the parameter
      Vector3d normalize()
      scales the vector to the length 1
      fails (does nothing than) for the zero-vector
      static Vector3d one() 
      static Vector3d random() 
      static Vector3d random2dxy() 
      static Vector3d random2dxz() 
      static Vector3d random2dyz() 
      static Vector3d right() 
      Vector3d rot(Vector3d axis, double rad)
      rotates this vector around the aligned axis in mathematically positive direction
      Vector3d rotX(double rad)
      rotates the vector around the x-axis in mathematically positive direction, means nicking
      mathematically positive means nick up
      Vector3d rotY(double rad)
      rotates the vector around the y-axis in mathematically positive direction, means turning
      mathematically positive means turn left
      Vector3d rotZ(double rad)
      rotates the vector around the z-axis in mathematically positive direction, means leaning
      mathematically positive means counter-clockwise
      Vector3d scale(double k)
      enlarges the vector by k, it's direction will be constant
      for k between 0 and 1, the vector will be shortened
      for negative k the vector will be inverted and then enlarged by positive k
      Vector3d scaleTo(double length)
      scales this vector to the length of the parameter-vector, but will not change this direction
      Vector3d scaleTo(Vector3d compare)
      scales this vector to the length of the parameter-vector, but will not change this direction
      the parameter will not be changed
      Vector3d set(double x, double y, double z)
      copies the coordinates of the parameter to this
      Vector3d set(Vector3d t)
      copies the coordinates of the parameter to this
      does not change the parameter
      Vector3d setCoordinates(double[] vec)
      counterpart to getCoordinates
      sets the coordinates of this to x=[0], y=[1], z=[2]
      Vector3d setToZero()
      sets all coordinates to 0
      Vector3d sub(Vector3d t)
      subtracts the coordinates of the parameter from the coordinates of this
      does not change the parameter
      Vector3d to(Vector3d t)
      does not change the parameter
      Vector3d toCartesian()
      converts this vectors polar coordinates (x=inclination (theta), y=azimuth (phi), z=distance) to Cartesian coordinates toCartesian().toPolar() should cause no change unless a rounding mistake
      Vector3d toPolar()
      converts this vectors Cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates
      a polar coordinates representation is given by two angles (new x-coordinate as inclination (theta), new y-coordinate as azimuth (phi)) and a distance (new z-coordinate) from the coordinate-center toPolar().toCartesian() should cause no change unless a rounding mistake
      java.lang.String toRoundedString(int decimalPlace)
      to display the vector in an user-appropriate form with x digits after the comma
      for negative parameters, the coordinates will be displayed rounded.
      java.lang.String toString() 
      static Vector3d up() 
      static Vector3d x()
      creates an independent vector with 1 as x-coordinate and 0 as all other coordinates
      static Vector3d y()
      creates an independent vector with 1 as y-coordinate and 0 as all other coordinates
      static Vector3d z()
      creates an independent vector with 1 as z-coordinate and 0 as all other coordinates
      static Vector3d zero()

      • toRoundedString

        public java.lang.String toRoundedString(int decimalPlace)
        to display the vector in an user-appropriate form with x digits after the comma
        for negative parameters, the coordinates will be displayed rounded.
        this will not be changed
        Parameters:
        decimalPlace - digits to display after comma
        Returns:
        an readable string-representation of the coordinates

      • scale

        public Vector3d scale(double k)
        enlarges the vector by k, it's direction will be constant
        for k between 0 and 1, the vector will be shortened
        for negative k the vector will be inverted and then enlarged by positive k
        Parameters:
        k - factor to enlarge
        Returns:
        a this-reference

        the parameter will not be changed
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        a this reference

      • normalize

        public Vector3d normalize()
        scales the vector to the length 1
        fails (does nothing than) for the zero-vector
        Returns:
        a this-reference

      • isParallel

        public boolean isParallel(Vector3d v)
        checks, whether the parameter-vector has the same direction
        it may have another length
        does not change the parameter
        Parameters:
        v - the Vector to check
        Returns:
        true if the parameter-vector has the same direction

      • getRatio

        public static double getRatio(Vector3d a,
                              Vector3d b)
        returns the ratio between the two given parallel vectors or Double.NaN if they are not parallel
        if given vectors a and b the ratio is defined as:
        a = ratio * b so that ratio = a / b;
        Parameters:
        a - the dividend
        b - the divisor
        Returns:
        the ratio

      • isOrthogonal

        public boolean isOrthogonal(Vector3d v)
        checks, whether the parameter-vector is orthogonal
        it may have another length
        Parameters:
        v - the Vector to check
        Returns:
        true if the parameter-vector is orthogonal to this, false otherwise

      • isSameOrientated

        public boolean isSameOrientated(Vector3d v)
        checks, whether the parameter-vector has the same direction and orientation
        it may have another length
        does not change the parameter
        Parameters:
        v - the Vector to check
        Returns:
        true if the parameter-vector has the same direction and is not inverted

      • dotP

        public double dotP(Vector3d v)
        calculates the dot-product of this and the parameter
        does not change both the parameter or this
        Parameters:
        v - the vector to calculate the dot-product with
        Returns:
        the dot-product between this and the parameter

      • crossP

        public Vector3d crossP(Vector3d b)
        the cross-product of two vectors is a vector that is orthogonal to the parameters
        it does matter in which order the parameters are given. In a reverse order, the result vector will be orientated inverted
        the result vector will be the third one for the right-hand-rule
        does not change both the parameter and this
        Parameters:
        b - the second vector
        Returns:
        an orthogonal vector to the two parameters

      • crossP

        public static Vector3d crossP(Vector3d a,
                              Vector3d b)
        the cross-product of two vectors is a vector that is orthogonal to the parameters
        it does matter in which order the parameters are given. In a reverse order, the result vector will be orientated inverted
        the result vector will be the third one for the right-hand-rule
        Parameters:
        a - the first vector
        b - the second vector
        Returns:
        an orthogonal vector to the two parameters

      • dotP

        public static double dotP(Vector3d a,
                          Vector3d b)
        the dot product of two vectors is an double that can represent part of the angle between the parameters
        the dotP is positive if the angle between the vectors is pointed, a negative value otherwise
        if the parameter-vectors are orthogonal, the result will be 0
        it does not matter in which order the parameters are given
        Parameters:
        a - the first vector
        b - the second vector
        Returns:
        the dot product of the vectors

      • invert

        public Vector3d invert()
        inverts this vector
        this will point in the opposite direction, but with the same length
        Returns:
        a this-reference

      • angleTo

        public double angleTo(Vector3d v)
        calculates the angle between this and the parameter-vector in radiant
        both vectors are direction-vectors and for that calculation interpreted as arrows laying on the 3d-space-origin
        does not change the parameter
        Parameters:
        v - the vector to calculate the angle of this to
        Returns:
        the radiant-angle to the parameter-vector

      • isZero

        public boolean isZero()
        checks all coordinates to be 0d
        Returns:
        true if so, false otherwise

      • isNormalized

        public boolean isNormalized()
        Returns:
        true if the length of this is 1d, false otherwise

      • calculateAverage

        public static Vector3d calculateAverage(Vector3d... vecs)
        the average vector is:
        does not change the parameter
        • the center position (if the given vectors were interpreted as positions)
        • the middle-direction (if the given vectors were interpreted as directions)
        Parameters:
        vecs - all vectors to calculate the average one
        Returns:
        the average vector of all given ones

      • getX

        public int getX()
        casts the x value to int
        Returns:
        int-value of x

        public int getY()
        casts the y value to int
        Returns:
        int-value of y

      • getZ

        public int getZ()
        casts the z value to int
        Returns:
        int-value of z

        public Vector3d set(Vector3d t)
        copies the coordinates of the parameter to this
        does not change the parameter
        Parameters:
        t - the new coordinates of this
        Returns:
        a this-reference

                    double y,
                    double z)
        copies the coordinates of the parameter to this
        Parameters:
        x - the new x-coordinate of this
        y - the new y-coordinate of this
        z - the new z-coordinate of this
        Returns:
        a this-reference

      • setToZero

        public Vector3d setToZero()
        sets all coordinates to 0
        Returns:
        a this-reference

      • zero

        public static Vector3d zero()
        Returns:
        an independent vector where all coordinates are 0d

      • one

        public static Vector3d one()
        Returns:
        an independent vector with x=y=z=1 and the length 1

      • up

        public static Vector3d up()
        Returns:
        an independent vector with x=z=0 and y=1

      • right

        public static Vector3d right()
        Returns:
        an independent vector with y=z=0 and x=1

      • forward

        public static Vector3d forward()
        Returns:
        an independent vector with x=y=0 and z=-1

      • random

        public static Vector3d random()
        Returns:
        a random normalized vector

      • random2dxy

        public static Vector3d random2dxy()
        Returns:
        a random normalized vector where z is 0

      • random2dxz

        public static Vector3d random2dxz()
        Returns:
        a random normalized vector where y is 0

      • random2dyz

        public static Vector3d random2dyz()
        Returns:
        a random normalized vector where x is 0

      • rotZ

        public Vector3d rotZ(double rad)
        rotates the vector around the z-axis in mathematically positive direction, means leaning
        mathematically positive means counter-clockwise
        Parameters:
        rad - the radiant angle to rotate
        Returns:
        a this reference

      • rotX

        public Vector3d rotX(double rad)
        rotates the vector around the x-axis in mathematically positive direction, means nicking
        mathematically positive means nick up
        Parameters:
        rad - the radiant angle to rotate
        Returns:
        a this reference

      • rotY

        public Vector3d rotY(double rad)
        rotates the vector around the y-axis in mathematically positive direction, means turning
        mathematically positive means turn left
        Parameters:
        rad - the radiant angle to rotate
        Returns:
        a this reference

      • rot

        public Vector3d rot(Vector3d axis,
                    double rad)
        rotates this vector around the aligned axis in mathematically positive direction
        Parameters:
        axis - the aligned axis to turn around (need not to be normalized)
        rad - the radiant angle to rotate
        Returns:
        a this reference

      • clipTo2dXY

        public Vector2d clipTo2dXY()
        just cut off the z-coordinate
        Returns:
        an independent 2 dimensional vector with the x and y coordinate of this

      • clipTo2dXZ

        public Vector2d clipTo2dXZ()
        just cut off the y-coordinate
        Returns:
        an independent 2 dimensional vector with the x and z coordinate of this as the x (is this.x) and y (is this.z) coordinates

      • clipTo2dYZ

        public Vector2d clipTo2dYZ()
        just cut off the x-coordinate
        Returns:
        an independent 2 dimensional vector with the y and z coordinate of this as the x (is this.y) and y (is this.z) coordinates

      • constrain

        public Vector3d constrain(double min,
                          double max)
        constrains the coordinates to the given range
        if a coordinate is lower than min, it will be set to min
        if a coordinate is higher than max, it will be set to max
        after this method call all coordinates will be within the interval [min,max], including the limits
        Parameters:
        min - the lower-limit
        max - the upper-limit
        Returns:
        a this reference

      • constrainLength

        public Vector3d constrainLength(double min,
                                double max)
        constrains the length to the given range
        if this length is lower than min, it will be scaled to min
        if this length is higher than max, it will be scaled to max
        Parameters:
        min - the lower-limit
        max - the upper-limit
        Returns:
        a this reference

      • x

        public static Vector3d x()
        creates an independent vector with 1 as x-coordinate and 0 as all other coordinates
        Returns:
        a vector with x=1, other coordinates = 0

      • y

        public static Vector3d y()
        creates an independent vector with 1 as y-coordinate and 0 as all other coordinates
        Returns:
        a vector with y=1, other coordinates = 0

      • z

        public static Vector3d z()
        creates an independent vector with 1 as z-coordinate and 0 as all other coordinates
        Returns:
        a vector with z=1, other coordinates = 0

      • toPolar

        public Vector3d toPolar()
        converts this vectors Cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates
        a polar coordinates representation is given by two angles (new x-coordinate as inclination (theta), new y-coordinate as azimuth (phi)) and a distance (new z-coordinate) from the coordinate-center

        toPolar().toCartesian() should cause no change unless a rounding mistake

        Returns:
        a this-reference
        See Also:
        toCartesian()

      • toCartesian

        public Vector3d toCartesian()
        converts this vectors polar coordinates (x=inclination (theta), y=azimuth (phi), z=distance) to Cartesian coordinates

        toCartesian().toPolar() should cause no change unless a rounding mistake

        Returns:
        a this-reference
        See Also:
        toPolar()

      • isFinite

        public static boolean isFinite(Vector3d v)
        checks whether the given vector is not null and all it's coordinates are finite
        Parameters:
        v - the vector to check
        Returns:
        whether the vector can be considered usable in general case
